name: Inside a Star-filled Sky
description: Inside a Star-filled Sky is an infinite, recursive, tactical shooter by award-winning designer Jason Rohrer (Passage, Between). What if you could enter an object in a level and find a level inside of it? What if you could enter an object in that level and find another level inside of that?
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 900 MHz Memory: 40 MBHard Disk Space: 10 MB Video Card: Onboard GraphicsSound: Standard Audio

reviews.review_text: Interesting concept and gameplay but nothing there to make you want to continue playing after an hour.

Frustratingly poor game design. Single idea with crap tacked ontop. Game doesn't have a menu, don't have a clue wtf I'm doing or if there are even any other buttons. WTF do flags do? Is there a ♥♥♥♥ing goal to the game? No? Good, so I won't have to worry about sleepless nights wondering what happens at the end. ♥♥♥♥it
I truely can't understand how I'm so addicted to this...

Inside a Star-Filled Sky is by far one of the most curious games I have played in a long time. Featuring a recursive level diving type system that allows you to go into your enemies, power ups and even yourself and change aspects of the respective object to change the game around. The gameplay itself is much like many other twin stick shooter type deals but a lot more tactical. I myself am not entirely sure who I'd recommend this to but it certainly is an interesting concept.
Indie game of the year for me. And, yes. I have played Bastion.
WHAT IF YOU COULD PLAY A GAME INSIDE AN POWERUP INSIDE A GAME INSIDE AN ENEMY INSIDE THE WALL INSIDE AN ENEMY.
